headline: Gluten-Free Tuesday: Vegan Banana Bread Muffins Recipe
description: Over the past few months, several Serious Eats readers requested gluten-free recipes that also avoid the "top eight." (The "top eight" in allergy-speak are the eight most common allergens: wheat, milk, eggs, soy, tree nuts, peanuts, fish, and shellfish.) Since multiple food allergies sometimes make breakfast tricky, I decided to make muffins.
name: Gluten-Free Tuesday: Vegan Banana Bread Muffins Recipe
recipeIngredient: 1 1/2 cups (about thee medium bananas) mashed*, very ripe bananas
*To mash, place bananas in a bowl. Use a fork and mash until smooth with no large pieces of bananas remain (small pieces of bananas are fine).

recipeInstructions.text: Adjust oven rack to middle position and preheat oven to 350Â°F. Line 14 standard muffin cups with paper liners or grease with a non-stick cooking spray. Set pans aside
In small bowl, combine mashed bananas and turbinado sugar. In another small bowl, combine flax meal and hot water. Stir to combine. Allow banana mixture and flax mixture to stand for 10 minutes.
In medium mixing bowl, whisk together brown rice flour, potato starch, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and xanthan gum. Set aside.
In large mixing bowl, cream shortening until light and fluffy, about 20 seconds. Add flax meal mixture. Cream until smooth. Scrape down bottom and sides of bowl.

Add half dry ingredients. Blend until smooth. Add banana-sugar mixture. Blend until well incorporated. Add remaining dry ingredients. Blend batter until smooth, about 20 seconds. Batter will be thick.

Fill muffin cups 2/3 full with batter. Bake muffins until deep golden brown, about 25 minutes. Transfer muffins to wire rack to cool. Store in an airtight container for up to four days or freeze up to one month.

review.reviewBody:
How many eggs do I use if I just want to use eggs instead of flax meal?
Thank you!

@JaysBaker--I believe swapping tapioca starch for potato will work. The muffins might have a bit more body (potato stach is a bit more tender) but since the amount of starch is so small, the change won't be too noticable!

Would tapioca flour be an acceptable substitute for the potato starch? My son is allergic to that as well and I know straight brown rice flour would increase the density of the muffins. Also, does a substitution of coconut oil cause a change in the flavor of the muffins? Thanks for all of your work in revamping this recipe! I can't wait to make them for my little man!

What happens if you omit the xanthan gum? I'm not clear on what it does and how necessary it really is. 

Thanks so much for thinking of the gluten-free folks!
Yum! I always appreciate banana bread as muffins because of the portion control. Thanks for sharing the recipe!
